text: David, go ahead and start the tapes. Okay, we're rolling. First of all, I just wondered if you might tell us a little bit about how you, the origin of the column in Locus that you write. Well, about two, two and a half years ago, I was invited to address a group of authors, the American Society of Journalists and Authors, And I chose to talk to them about certain contractual clauses that I thought might be pitfalls for most professional authors. In the questioning that followed, I found an appalling ignorance on the part of authors on the subject of contracts. And many of these people are highly respected professional journalists journalists and book authors. And yet it was clear to me that they didn't know anything, or very much I should say, about how to read a contract, how to negotiate one, and how to alter a clause to their own benefit. And so I decided to write a column for the many other writers who probably are in the same position. And I asked Charles Brown, the editor of Locus, a publisher of Locus, I guess, whether he'd be interested in publishing it and it was quite agreeable and thereafter a number of magazines newsletters published by other writers groups such as Western Writers of America Romance Writers of America Mystery Writers of America took on the column because they felt their authors were in the same position so actually LOCUS then was your first magazine of that type that you wrote the column for yes LOCUS was I still consider myself as writing the column for LOCUS ok fine would you be would you be allowed to tell me which science fiction authors or just some of them that you do represent well no I don't mind at all I think it's fairly common knowledge in the science fiction community we represent Harlan Ellison Gregory Benford, Greg Baer, Elizabeth Lynn, Marta Randall, Barry Longyear, Warren Norwood, Jessica Salminson, and I'd say three or four more. Okay. If you had to sell a decent manuscript by an unknown author, Would you prefer to work with a romance, a western, a mystery, a science fiction, or what sort of genre of literature? Well, my orientation has always been the paperback original market. Not that my agency doesn't handle hardcovers. We handle quite a lot of them, dozens and dozens hardcovers, and many have been on the bestseller list and book club selections and so forth. But the blood of the industry is the paperback market, and the paperback market does break down into some fairly convenient genres. And agents, I guess, are a little bit like nomads in that they follow the source of life. In this case, for instance, the hot market right now is contemporary romances, And so we have a very active department in contemporary romances. Science fiction has become somewhat soft since the Star Trek, Star Wars phenomenon. and although it's still a very active market, we have noticed a kind of sorting out of important writers from what they call the mid-list writers, that is to say those writers who aren't quite of the blockbuster or best-seller category and yet they're better than what some people might refer to as, you know, as hack writers. They find themselves in a market where there really isn't an audience anymore. So we have found that writers really have to choose between going to something else or becoming stars in the science fiction market. There's no middle ground anymore. And that's true of just about all the genres, westerns. Romance may be the place that is most open for new writers, inexperienced writers. But in the science fiction world, I think you must start with some advantage or you're going to have a tough struggle ahead of you. I think we've never spoken to an agent before and from your perspective I think you can answer certain questions that I think anybody else would have difficulty answering and one of them I wanted to ask you is from your perspective what determines the popularity of a genre of literature in paperback is it the publishers who create the taste or what causes sometimes the publishers create the taste and sometimes the market the consumer creates the demand, and sometimes it's the agent. For instance, I find myself very often in speaking to publishers, I find myself in a double role. I keep my ears open and try to listen to what a publisher tells me about what he's able to sell and what he's not able to sell, and so I have a kind of passive role and that I pass along to authors what the publishers tell me the market is doing. However, if I begin to notice a trend, I then try to help create a market by turning to other publishers and saying, listen, I've had lunch the last couple of months with four publishers and they all tell me that hard science fiction is not as active as fantasy and swords and sorcery and so maybe you'd be interested in some sort of sorcery. So an agent is in the position of shaping the market once he begins to detect the trend. Okay, that was interesting. I guess after reading your columns, of course, I'm coming to understand how much influence an agent can have. I don't think I realized that before. Okay, I think I know the answer to this. In fact, most of the questions I'm asking you, I have some idea of what you'll say because of what I've read of your work, but I still need to ask it. I know that you have different contracts for different clients or different authors, but say a contract with any sort of author, not just science fiction, is it dependent upon if an author is new or established according to what kind of contract he gets? Well, I think authors and agents probably ought to try to penetrate through a lot of the haze that surrounds contractual negotiations and realize that the essential in a contractual negotiation is who has the power. For the beginning author, the first author, or the author of some work for minor markets, the power definitely rests with the publisher. The publisher, the author, in effect, is saying to the publisher, I will sign anything you hand me if you publish me. And the publisher says, well, I'm glad to hear that, because if you don't like our terms, we'll find somebody else to write for us. Now, obviously, the power in that equation lies with the publisher. However, as an author begins to develop, he has a following. His books begin to sell. The prices that he gets for his work begin to escalate. He may have a bestseller. He now has other publishers interested in publishing him. And now the equation is on the other foot, if I may make some metaphor. And it's now the author who says, the publisher says, I will do anything to keep you. And the author says, well, then you'd better meet my terms because there are plenty of publishers out there who will publish me if you don't like what I have, the terms that I'm ready to dictate. So when you get down to where this raw power and the agent tries to put himself in those power vectors, I guess you would say, and get some sense of where they converge. And that's the point at which a contract materializes. A contract is a direct reflection of the power flow between the two parties. And at the point where they all interface, that is what a contract reads. That's excellent. Very good. you talk just like you write I think I'm not sure that's good or bad listen science fiction fans are I think more fanatic than other types and a lot of them of course are interested in writing and doing something besides just reading it if somebody had a reasonable amount of talent what would you advise an aspiring science fiction author where should you begin always begin with the magazines you're absolutely right about science fiction fans being more fanatic. But they are also fortunate in having a place where they can begin in the shorter media where most writers in other genres don't have the chance. I mean, there are very few places where a romance writer can teethe. You know, you can't write romance short stories unless you write for try to write for some of the slicker women's magazines and they're of course very demanding in what they accept there used to be western magazines many many of them but those almost all of them are gone now mystery magazines there are still a couple of them but it's not like what it used to be when I got into the business about 25 years ago so So one of the few remaining genres that invites new talent and cultivates it is science fiction, where you have very active magazine market and anthology market for original stories. You also have conventions. Of course, Western writers, romance writers, mystery writers also have their conventions. but certainly science fiction writers can out-convention anybody by a ratio of 10 to 1. So there's a lot of interplay where authors are always talking to one another, meeting editors, meeting professional writers, and there's a much tighter unity than there is in any other genre. So I would definitely advise any aspiring science fiction writer to start writing in the magazines. In fact, even some of my well-known clients, I still tell them to continue writing for science fiction magazines, even though they may get peanuts for their work compared to what they can get writing books, because the exposure among both science fiction editors and science fiction fans is terribly important. Okay, I just have about one or two more on science fiction and get on to some more general things. Would you happen to be working with any unpublished authors at present in science fiction that we might look for? That question kind of catches me unaware. We have a number of people that we are establishing. It's very hard to say because in spite of what I said a few moments ago about getting published in magazines, like most other agents, we handle very little by way of short fiction. It's not profitable for an agent to handle science fiction stories. There's very little that we can do for a short story writer that he or she can't do for him or herself. By the time an author comes to us asking for representation, and we think that person might be interesting. He's probably had quite a number of stories published in the science fiction magazines. I will mention one, one author that I think is enormously talented and will probably burst on the scenes within the next couple of years, and that's a writer named Dan Simmons, who's beginning to make some appearances in Omni and some of the other magazines. He's a very, very talented writer, and we are about to take on some of his longer work. Okay, one more on science fiction. I should accord my thanks to Harlan Ellison, who was the first person to spot him, and refer him to me. Okay, good. One more on science fiction. Are you working on selling, or do you have in your hands any big manuscripts from some of your name authors that might be published in the near future? Well, Gregory Benford has the author of Timescape, which was the Nebula Award winner in the novel category for 1981, has two novels coming out in the next year. One is Against Infinity, which is coming out in April. Will be published by Timescape Books in hardcover, a wonderful novel. And I believe next February, we will see Across the Sea of Suns, which is the sequel to In the Ocean of Night, and is the second novel in a trilogy. We also have what I consider a great novel in the making by Richard Grant, who's made some appearances in magazines, but turned in a spectacular novel, which is now being shaped somewhat and redone, but it's some of the most brilliant writing I've ever read. Those who have had an early look at it agree with me that it's a very impressive job. And I know that when that book is finished, I believe it's got bestseller written all over it. Okay, do you like trilogies? Yes, I like them and I encourage them. I feel they're a very comfortable form for science fiction writers. In fact, for non-science fiction writers as well. The beauty of a trilogy, of course, from an agent's viewpoint, is in the kind of package deal that one can make where you not only sign an author up for a book, but you can sign him up for a sequel and a sequel after that. And the author knows where he's going to be two years from now. The publisher knows what he can expect over a couple of years. And unless the author one day runs out of steam or gets bored with the characters that he developed in book one or two, you can see a cumulative effect in the sales of a trilogy where publication of Book 2 makes people scurry for Book 1, and publication of Book 3 causes the publisher to reissue Books 1 and 2, and then they put them in a box set, and they're reviewed as a whole. It's a very nice way of publishing books, but not everybody has a sequel in them. Right. Why does an author with reasonable talent need an agent? But there are very few authors who, once they achieve publication, are really able or even want to handle their own business until you become a full-blooded professional writer with a track record. As I said before, most of your job is writing your magazine stuff, sending it out, and developing a magazine market. But once you begin selling, unless you really understand contractual language, then you're going to need an agent to interpret it for you. Also, most authors are not as objective about their work as an agent can be, and therefore they either demand too much or too riddle when they negotiate a contract. So an agent can help put things in perspective and can talk both publishers and authors into being reasonable. Agents can also exploit subsidiary rights that authors are only dimly aware of. And agents, finally, are able to help build an author's career by spotting that author's strengths and weaknesses and building, of course, on the strengths and developing their talents to the utmost. There are a few authors I know, most notably Isaac Asimov, who I don't believe have agents or at least not regular agents. And Isaac certainly has done okay for himself, although I think there are probably five dozen agents who have said to him, think how well you would have done if you'd had an agent. But most authors sooner or later feel that it is well worth the commission and other things to have somebody, particularly when you don't live in the New York area, which is the heart of the publishing world. If you live in California or Nebraska or something like that, there's nothing so frightening as to be out of touch with a publisher and not having anybody that you can call to act on your behalf. Okay, a more personal question. Your book, How to Be Your Own Literary Agent, of course I haven't seen that yet, But are you trying to put yourself out of business with that? I don't think I will, for the reasons that I just told you. The title may not be exactly accurate because, although it is designed to help new authors get a foot in the door that they might not otherwise have, It's also aimed at the professional author who may have an agent who may be of the kind who simply signs on the dotted line when his agent sticks a contract under his nose. And those authors, I think, are usually the ones who end up discovering a couple of years down the road that they made a horrible mistake when they signed that contract. and why didn't their agent tell them about certain things. And so my feeling is that an enlightened author is probably an agent's best friend, whether he's represented by an agent or not. The more that an author knows about contracts and related subjects, the tougher he's going to be in dealing with publishers and the more he's going to benefit the entire fraternity and sorority of authors in this country and make an agent's job easier. So I don't feel that I've contradicted myself by publishing a book called How to Be Your Own Literary Agent. Okay, as the title indicates then, that really is a how-to book. Well, it does tell you, for instance, if you're a new author, It tells you what genres are the likeliest ones to buy your work, how to write for them, how to package your work for them, how to get your work on the desk of an editor and avoid the so-called flush pile. It tells you what to do if you should get an offer. It tells you how to negotiate on your own. it tells you how to oversee what your agent is doing if you should decide to, uh, turn your work over to an agent. It tells you how to hire and fire an agent. And, uh, it is, it completely analyzes publishing contracts from start to finish, um, and interprets each clause in a way that any author can certainly get an advantage by, uh, studying, uh, my suggestions. So really, I guess even a beginner would get some good out of the book. Absolutely. Okay, good. And when will that be out again? Let's see. Today is the 15th. Three days is the official publication date. February 18th. Okay, very good. It's already created something of a controversy in New York, because one of the chapters in the book is a somewhat outspoken attack on publishing accounting systems. Publishers have a tendency to do what I call creative accounting, which the bottom line is that they hold, hide, or misguide authors as to how much in royalties they're entitled to. A couple of days ago, the New York Times picked up on that chapter and published an article under the headline, Agent Says Publishers Are Cheating Authors. So we've got what I consider a very healthy controversy going, and certainly one that every author ought to be interested in, because it really is the gut issue. I know many new authors and aspiring authors, all they want to know is who's going to publish my book, and whatever they pay me, whatever advance I get, is fine with me. But as they become more and more professional and experienced, They may wake up one day and realize that they're not getting everything that's owing to them because the publishers have obscured some of the royalty reporting systems that would enable an author to get his full due. And so I've tried to dispel some of the mystery around the reading of royalty statements and so authors can get a better idea of what is being told to them and whether any money is being hidden. Okay, in reading your columns over a period of time, I think I've caught you saying a couple times that even with a lot of talent and even with a great manuscript, writers still may not make it because of the way the publishing industry is set up. Is that sort of a cynical attitude on your part? Well, I don't say it with any pride. I say it with a great deal of sadness. Many, in the last couple of years, the prices of books have gone prohibitively high. A hardcover novel these days sells for anywhere from $15 to $20, and a paperback novel sells anywhere from $3 to $5 or even a little more. and the consumer the book buyer is shying away from the marketplace now because he seems to feel there are better ways to spend $20 or $5 even as a result the book sales have been dropping and the publishers have become more and more selective as to what they buy unfortunately that all gets passed down to the author and more and more frequently in the last couple of years I have had to turn away as all my colleagues in the agency business have had to do I've had to turn away a number of very good books that were well written but didn't really fit into certain categories that I know are actively buying, and so what you end up with is a well-written book that really isn't saleable, and it can often break your heart to send a book like that back. It doesn't hurt you as much to send back a bad book as it does to send back a good one, but there's nothing guaranteeing that a good book is going to sell, and that I would say is possibly the major difference between publishing today and publishing 10 years ago. Okay, one more follow-up on that. Does the system, as you described it, lead to sort of hack writing, or writing that's not very good? No, quite the contrary. I think the level of writing is getting better because publishers don't need to publish hack writing anymore when they can get so many good writers. The market has shrunk. For instance, the paperback field, whereas about two or three years ago, there were, I would say, 13 active viable paperbacks ranging from the modest size ones to the giant. Several have gone out of business, and three or four more have been absorbed into other companies, and now one can count six or seven paperback publishers left. and so the clamor to be published by those houses is increasing and so the publishers can afford to be more selective than ever before. So my feeling is that, although I don't like to use the word hack, that certainly the inferior writer is either going to have to try harder or he's going to drop out because there are just too many good writers waiting to take his place. Okay, Mr. Curtis I have about I want to move I have about 10 minutes left if you can spare that I wanted to talk about some personal things about your background and your own work if you have the time for that Absolutely Okay, I was going to say how does one become an agent, but I guess I better ask how you became one Well when I think for a long time I always wanted to be a writer and when I got out of college, I discovered that there were no real jobs for writers, so I decided to get into a related field, publishing. I could not find a job at a publishing company, so I finally ended up working for a leading literary agency, Scott Merida, and there I stayed for some seven or eight years, and that was my apprenticeship. and after some seven years I really did have an itch to write and so I had been writing even while I worked for Scott Merida so I left that firm and became a freelance writer and of course having been an agent I was much better connected than most freelance writers could ever hope to be so the transition was not as hard for me as it would be if somebody left some other job. I did a lot of magazine work, but eventually realized that the magazine market was in its twilight, and began focusing on books. I wrote a lot of paperback novels, and then eventually got into such areas as collaboration, books on conservation. I found that I had a forte in the area of humor so I did a number of satirical books I wrote just about anything that people would pay money for and it was a very very good grounding and after about five years of that a number of my old clients looked me up and asked me if I would represent them and since I was not making a fortune as a writer in spite of the fact that to date I've had about 45 books published, I decided that perhaps I would go back into agenting, and I started my own firm, and for two or three years, I was both a writer and a literary agent. Literally, I had two desks back to back with a swivel chair between them, and in the morning I would do one thing and in the afternoon I would do another and I would try not to let one contaminate the other. And eventually, when I discovered that I could make more money on a few phone calls as an agent than I could for four or five months writing books, it was pretty clear to me where my career was heading. But I have not given up my writing. The column, of course, is very satisfying. And from time to time, I might take a crack at a commercial novel or a nonfiction book. I get up at five or six in the morning, I'll write for an hour or so, then I'll go to work, and although an hour a day may not seem like a lot, as most professional writers will tell you, over a period of a couple of months, one can write a book at an hour a day as long as you stay with it and turn out something every day. So I do consider myself a literary agent with a side order of writing. In looking over the books that I know you've written in the past few years, it seems to me that a lot of your nonfiction books have been dealing with issues of social concern, like the nuclear lessons, the inequality in American communities, and so forth. Is that because of personal taste or because of your collaborator? Well, I take some pride in some of the work that I've done in the area of conservation. In around 1970 or so, I was approached by a woman who had accumulated a great deal of quite terrifying information about the nuclear power industry. And she asked me to collaborate with her. I knew very little about it, but I did work with her. And out of that collaboration came a book that was published by Doubleday called Perils of the Peaceful Atom. It was the first popular book on the dangers of nuclear power plants. And although it was supplanted later on by books published by people, authorities, scientists, and PhDs, whereas we were only laymen and women, I like to think that that book did open the door to discussion of the nuclear power issues, which finally culminated in the Three Mile Island accident years later. And I was able to say that I had told you so. Many of the things that happened were predicted in that book years earlier, and of course nobody really wanted to listen. I have written some other books of social value I'm very proud of them I'm also, if I may add very proud of an agent to have brought into the world many books on social issues and things like that we recently handled a magnificent first novel about the Vietnam War called The Thirteenth Valley, which went on the bestseller list, and opened the door to what I know will now be a state of Vietnam fiction. Up until that time, people had said that nobody really wanted to read about Vietnam, and so we've now enabled some fresh air to blow into the marketplace with that novel. and again, this is an accomplishment that I'm very proud of. What about your fiction, your novels? Could you give me an idea of what kind of things you write about, and if they sell well? Well, a couple of years ago, while I was still full, well, more than that, about a decade ago, So I conceived a paperback series featuring a hero that I always thought was rather unusual. He was a detective in the area of sports. And a series of books featuring this hero was, the series was called The Pro, and the books were published by Warner. We did four of those, and at the moment I'm trying to revive that series or something along those lines because right now, although there's a great deal of male action-adventure fiction being published, everybody's getting bored with the same old heroes, the mercenaries, the dirty dozens, and a series like that. And so I'm trying to get revived, this hero that I think is a rather refreshing one. But I'm not able to do too much in the fiction area simply because of time. Okay, I just have a couple more here. I remember reading one of your columns where you mentioned, I guess it was an innovation on your part as an agent where you contracted with a publicity firm for your clients and so forth. I wondered if things like that that you've done for your clients might be a little different or innovative or whatever. Well, every agent, of course, is trying to seek a better way to handle his clients and more advantages for his clients. and one of the things that upsets me deeply is the fact that publishers are very reluctant to spend promotional money on any authors except the big-name celebrity authors. and so I attempted a couple of years ago to rectify that by asking my clients in effect to chip in each one of them would be in effect taxed a couple of extra percentage points of commission and that tax would go towards a fund which we used to hire a publicity agent who would publicize The Little Guy. And some of the campaigns were quite successful. Some aspects of the campaign were not so successful. And it was because of the inconsistency of the results that we finally dropped the program. But some of it has had lasting results and it certainly created a lot of talk in the industry and among authors. And it was, I thought, a noble experiment in the area of getting the lesser-known authors publicized. But it's still difficult. The market inclines towards the big name, and the struggle to become a big name is extremely intense, and very, very few people emerge. Okay, what about movie deals for books that are worthy of it? Do you actively seek them out, or do movie houses come to you? Well, it's a combination. Most books that are published that are of any value at all are covered by the movie studios, producers, and the people in New York whose job it is to scout on behalf of various Hollywood interests. So the chances are that if an agent is handling a good book at all, it will have been seen in one way or another by producers, directors, studio people and so forth. but they have amazing ways of getting hold of manuscripts, no matter how secretive you try to be. And so long before you're ready to show them, they've already been exposed. Nevertheless, if we get a hot manuscript and we really think it's going to make a terrific book, we actively try to find a movie producer for it. And so sometimes the deals come to us and sometimes we generate them. Okay, that's about I mean, there's lots of questions I could keep on talking for a long time but I think we have enough and we've taken enough of your time But listen, is there anything anything I haven't asked that you think listeners should know or anything at all that you'd like to talk about while we still have some tape left? No, I'd be happy to answer any other questions you may have Um, I will say that, uh, uh, we were talking about innovations before. Um, I may be springing a very radical, uh, proposition on the publishing industry that I believe will create a lot of talk and controversy, and I'm not doing it just to publicize myself, but I've begun to, uh, because of my deep concern about royalty accounting, uh, and and how publishers have managed to manipulate and hide authors' royalties, I'm going to be making a proposal to the publishing industry about a radically different way of accounting royalties based not on sales, but on copies printed. And I would say that within the next few months, you might begin looking for some stirring in that area and I believe it could have some rather radical effects on the way people think about the traditional way of accounting royalties. Yeah, I remember some of your columns, I think you sort of hinted at certain things about the way the publishers did that. Right. Well, I actually do suggest something like it in my book, but I will now be amplifying on it And if I can get some of the publishing media to pick up on these suggestions, it should make for very, very lively dialogue, and certainly one that's well overdue in this 18th century business we call publishing. Well, I'd take it, then, in the, let's say, the three-part relationship here, a writer, an agent, and a publisher, that you would say probably the publisher has much the best of it? No, I don't think so at all. So I've heard everybody accuse everybody else of having the best of it. There are rich agents, there are agents who are struggling, there are rich authors and authors who are struggling, and there are rich publishers and there are publishers who are struggling. I, in spite of some of the belligerent things I may have said, I have a great, great many friends among the publishers and I want to see them do well. And so I've come to think of it as a symbiotic environment in which everybody really does depend on everybody else. And an agent's job is not just to negotiate contracts, but to negotiate interests so that nobody gets so badly hurt that he can't carry on. I mean, publishers are always complaining about their overhead, and it's well to remind them that agents have to pay their rent also. But some agents get very greedy, and they feel that the only way for an author to become famous is to pin the publisher to the wall with a cruel deal. and sometimes that can backfire in terms of how much money is left after you've hit a publisher that hard, how much money is left for the struggling author. The paperback publisher that consistently pays $2 or $3 million for one or two authors is going to find himself neglecting the new author because he can't afford to pay him, or if he should buy a new author's work, he won't have any money left to publicize or promote that author's book. So there's something even to be said for not being greedy on behalf of your authors and giving the publisher an even break. Okay, very good. Okay, listen, we're going to turn off the recorder.

segments.text: David, go ahead and start the tapes.
Okay, we're rolling.
First of all, I just wondered if you might tell us a little bit about how you,
the origin of the column in Locus that you write.
Well, about two, two and a half years ago,
I was invited to address a group of authors,
the American Society of Journalists and Authors,
And I chose to talk to them
about certain contractual clauses
that I thought might be pitfalls
for most professional authors.
In the questioning that followed,
I found an appalling ignorance
on the part of authors
on the subject of contracts.
And many of these people
are highly respected professional journalists
journalists and book authors.
And yet it was clear to me that they didn't know anything,
or very much I should say,
about how to read a contract, how to negotiate one,
and how to alter a clause to their own benefit.
And so I decided to write a column for the many other writers
who probably are in the same position.
And I asked Charles Brown, the editor of Locus,
a publisher of Locus, I guess,
whether he'd be interested in publishing it
and it was quite agreeable
and thereafter a number of magazines
newsletters published by other writers groups
such as Western Writers of America
Romance Writers of America
Mystery Writers of America
took on the column
because they felt their authors
were in the same position
so actually LOCUS then
was your first magazine of that type
that you wrote the column for
yes LOCUS was
I still consider myself
as writing the column for LOCUS
ok fine
would you be
would you be allowed to tell me
which science fiction authors
or just some of them
that you do represent
well no I don't mind at all
I think it's fairly common knowledge
in the science fiction community
we represent Harlan Ellison
Gregory Benford,
Greg Baer,
Elizabeth Lynn,
Marta Randall,
Barry Longyear,
Warren Norwood,
Jessica Salminson,
and I'd say three or four more.
Okay.
If you had to sell a decent manuscript
by an unknown author,
Would you prefer to work with a romance, a western, a mystery, a science fiction,
or what sort of genre of literature?
Well, my orientation has always been the paperback original market.
Not that my agency doesn't handle hardcovers.
We handle quite a lot of them, dozens and dozens hardcovers,
and many have been on the bestseller list and book club selections and so forth.
But the blood of the industry is the paperback market,
and the paperback market does break down into some fairly convenient genres.
And agents, I guess, are a little bit like nomads in that they follow the source of life.
In this case, for instance, the hot market right now is contemporary romances,
And so we have a very active department in contemporary romances.
Science fiction has become somewhat soft since the Star Trek, Star Wars phenomenon.
and although it's still a very active market,
we have noticed a kind of sorting out of important writers
from what they call the mid-list writers,
that is to say those writers who aren't quite of the blockbuster or best-seller category
and yet they're better than what some people might refer to as, you know, as hack writers.
They find themselves in a market where there really isn't an audience anymore.
So we have found that writers really have to choose
between going to something else or becoming stars in the science fiction market.
There's no middle ground anymore.
And that's true of just about all the genres, westerns. Romance may be the place that is most open for new writers, inexperienced writers.
But in the science fiction world, I think you must start with some advantage or you're going to have a tough struggle ahead of you.
I think we've never spoken to an agent before
and from your perspective
I think you can answer certain questions
that I think anybody else
would have difficulty answering
and one of them I wanted to ask you
is from your perspective
what determines the popularity
of a genre of literature in paperback
is it the publishers who create the taste
or what causes
sometimes the publishers create the taste
and sometimes the market
the consumer creates the demand, and sometimes it's the agent.
For instance, I find myself very often in speaking to publishers, I find myself in a double role.
I keep my ears open and try to listen to what a publisher tells me about what he's able to sell
and what he's not able to sell, and so I have a kind of passive role
and that I pass along to authors what the publishers tell me the market is doing.
However, if I begin to notice a trend,
I then try to help create a market by turning to other publishers
and saying, listen, I've had lunch the last couple of months with four publishers
and they all tell me that hard science fiction is not as active as fantasy and swords and sorcery
and so maybe you'd be interested in some sort of sorcery.
So an agent is in the position of shaping the market
once he begins to detect the trend.
Okay, that was interesting.
I guess after reading your columns, of course,
I'm coming to understand how much influence an agent can have.
I don't think I realized that before.
Okay, I think I know the answer to this.
In fact, most of the questions I'm asking you,
I have some idea of what you'll say because of what I've read of your work,
but I still need to ask it.
I know that you have different contracts for different clients or different authors,
but say a contract with any sort of author, not just science fiction,
is it dependent upon if an author is new or established
according to what kind of contract he gets?
Well, I think authors and agents probably ought to try to penetrate
through a lot of the haze that surrounds contractual negotiations
and realize that the essential in a contractual negotiation
is who has the power.
For the beginning author, the first author,
or the author of some work for minor markets,
the power definitely rests with the publisher.
The publisher, the author, in effect, is saying to the publisher, I will sign anything you hand me if you publish me.
And the publisher says, well, I'm glad to hear that, because if you don't like our terms, we'll find somebody else to write for us.
Now, obviously, the power in that equation lies with the publisher.
However, as an author begins to develop, he has a following.
His books begin to sell.
The prices that he gets for his work begin to escalate.
He may have a bestseller.
He now has other publishers interested in publishing him.
And now the equation is on the other foot, if I may make some metaphor.
And it's now the author who says, the publisher says, I will do anything to keep you.
And the author says, well, then you'd better meet my terms because there are plenty of publishers out there
who will publish me if you don't like what I have, the terms that I'm ready to dictate.
So when you get down to where this raw power and the agent tries to put himself in those power vectors,
I guess you would say, and get some sense of where they converge.
And that's the point at which a contract materializes.
A contract is a direct reflection of the power flow between the two parties.
And at the point where they all interface, that is what a contract reads.
That's excellent. Very good.

So one of the few remaining genres that invites new talent and cultivates it is science fiction,
where you have very active magazine market and anthology market for original stories.
You also have conventions.
Of course, Western writers, romance writers, mystery writers also have their conventions.
but certainly science fiction writers can out-convention anybody by a ratio of 10 to 1.
So there's a lot of interplay
where authors are always talking to one another,
meeting editors, meeting professional writers,
and there's a much tighter unity than there is in any other genre.
So I would definitely advise any aspiring science fiction writer to start writing in the magazines.
In fact, even some of my well-known clients, I still tell them to continue writing for science fiction magazines,
even though they may get peanuts for their work compared to what they can get writing books,
because the exposure among both science fiction editors and science fiction fans is terribly important.
Okay, I just have about one or two more on science fiction and get on to some more general things.
Would you happen to be working with any unpublished authors at present in science fiction that we might look for?
That question kind of catches me unaware.
We have a number of people that we are establishing.
It's very hard to say because in spite of what I said a few moments ago about getting published in magazines,
like most other agents, we handle very little by way of short fiction.
It's not profitable for an agent to handle science fiction stories.
There's very little that we can do for a short story writer that he or she can't do for him or herself.
By the time an author comes to us asking for representation,
and we think that person might be interesting.
He's probably had quite a number of stories published in the science fiction magazines.
I will mention one, one author that I think is enormously talented
and will probably burst on the scenes within the next couple of years,
and that's a writer named Dan Simmons,
who's beginning to make some appearances in Omni
and some of the other magazines.
He's a very, very talented writer,
and we are about to take on some of his longer work.
Okay, one more on science fiction.
I should accord my thanks to Harlan Ellison,
who was the first person to spot him,
and refer him to me.
Okay, good.
One more on science fiction.
Are you working on selling, or do you have in your hands any big manuscripts from some
of your name authors that might be published in the near future?
Well, Gregory Benford has the author of Timescape, which was the Nebula Award winner in the novel
category for 1981, has two novels coming out in the next year.
One is Against Infinity, which is coming out in April.
Will be published by Timescape Books in hardcover, a wonderful novel.
And I believe next February, we will see Across the Sea of Suns,
which is the sequel to In the Ocean of Night,
and is the second novel in a trilogy.

We also have what I consider a great novel in the making by Richard Grant, who's made some appearances in magazines, but turned in a spectacular novel, which is now being shaped somewhat and redone, but it's some of the most brilliant writing I've ever read.
Those who have had an early look at it agree with me that it's a very impressive job.
And I know that when that book is finished, I believe it's got bestseller written all over it.
Okay, do you like trilogies?
Yes, I like them and I encourage them.
I feel they're a very comfortable form for science fiction writers.
In fact, for non-science fiction writers as well.
The beauty of a trilogy, of course, from an agent's viewpoint,
is in the kind of package deal that one can make
where you not only sign an author up for a book,
but you can sign him up for a sequel and a sequel after that.
And the author knows where he's going to be two years from now.
The publisher knows what he can expect over a couple of years.
And unless the author one day runs out of steam
or gets bored with the characters that he developed in book one or two,
you can see a cumulative effect in the sales of a trilogy
where publication of Book 2 makes people scurry for Book 1,
and publication of Book 3 causes the publisher to reissue Books 1 and 2,
and then they put them in a box set, and they're reviewed as a whole.
It's a very nice way of publishing books, but not everybody has a sequel in them.
Right. Why does an author with reasonable talent need an agent?
But there are very few authors who, once they achieve publication, are really able or even want to handle their own business until you become a full-blooded professional writer with a track record.
As I said before, most of your job is writing your magazine stuff,
sending it out, and developing a magazine market.
But once you begin selling, unless you really understand contractual language,
then you're going to need an agent to interpret it for you.
Also, most authors are not as objective about their work as an agent can be,
and therefore they either demand too much or too riddle when they negotiate a contract.
So an agent can help put things in perspective
and can talk both publishers and authors into being reasonable.
Agents can also exploit subsidiary rights
that authors are only dimly aware of.
And agents, finally, are able to help build an author's career
by spotting that author's strengths and weaknesses
and building, of course, on the strengths
and developing their talents to the utmost.
There are a few authors I know,
most notably Isaac Asimov,
who I don't believe have agents or at least not regular agents.
And Isaac certainly has done okay for himself,
although I think there are probably five dozen agents who have said to him,
think how well you would have done if you'd had an agent.
But most authors sooner or later feel that it is well worth the commission
and other things to have somebody,
particularly when you don't live in the New York area,
which is the heart of the publishing world.
If you live in California or Nebraska or something like that,
there's nothing so frightening as to be out of touch with a publisher
and not having anybody that you can call to act on your behalf.
Okay, a more personal question.
Your book, How to Be Your Own Literary Agent,
of course I haven't seen that yet,
But are you trying to put yourself out of business with that?
I don't think I will, for the reasons that I just told you.
The title may not be exactly accurate because, although it is designed to help new authors get a foot in the door that they might not otherwise have,
It's also aimed at the professional author who may have an agent who may be of the kind who simply signs on the dotted line when his agent sticks a contract under his nose.
And those authors, I think, are usually the ones who end up discovering a couple of years down the road that they made a horrible mistake when they signed that contract.
and why didn't their agent tell them about certain things.
And so my feeling is that an enlightened author is probably an agent's best friend,
whether he's represented by an agent or not.
The more that an author knows about contracts and related subjects,
the tougher he's going to be in dealing with publishers
and the more he's going to benefit the entire fraternity and sorority of
authors in this country and make an agent's job easier.
So I don't feel that I've contradicted myself by publishing a book called
How to Be Your Own Literary Agent.
Okay, as the title indicates then, that really is a how-to book.
Well, it does tell you, for instance, if you're a new author,
It tells you what genres are the likeliest ones to buy your work,
how to write for them, how to package your work for them,
how to get your work on the desk of an editor and avoid the so-called flush pile.
It tells you what to do if you should get an offer.
It tells you how to negotiate on your own.
it tells you how to oversee what your agent is doing if you should decide to, uh, turn your
work over to an agent. It tells you how to hire and fire an agent. And, uh, it is, it completely
analyzes publishing contracts from start to finish, um, and interprets each clause in a way
that any author can certainly get an advantage by, uh, studying, uh, my suggestions.
So really, I guess even a beginner would get some good out of the book.
Absolutely.
Okay, good. And when will that be out again?
Let's see. Today is the 15th. Three days is the official publication date.
February 18th.
Okay, very good.
It's already created something of a controversy in New York,
because one of the chapters in the book is a somewhat outspoken attack on publishing accounting systems.
Publishers have a tendency to do what I call creative accounting,
which the bottom line is that they hold, hide, or misguide authors
as to how much in royalties they're entitled to.
A couple of days ago, the New York Times picked up on that chapter
and published an article under the headline,
Agent Says Publishers Are Cheating Authors.
So we've got what I consider a very healthy controversy going,
and certainly one that every author ought to be interested in,
because it really is the gut issue.
I know many new authors and aspiring authors,
all they want to know is who's going to publish my book,
and whatever they pay me, whatever advance I get, is fine with me.
But as they become more and more professional and experienced,
They may wake up one day and realize that they're not getting everything that's owing to them
because the publishers have obscured some of the royalty reporting systems
that would enable an author to get his full due.
And so I've tried to dispel some of the mystery around the reading of royalty statements
and so authors can get a better idea of what is being told to them
and whether any money is being hidden.
Okay, in reading your columns over a period of time,
I think I've caught you saying a couple times that even with a lot of talent
and even with a great manuscript, writers still may not make it
because of the way the publishing industry is set up.
Is that sort of a cynical attitude on your part?
Well, I don't say it with any pride.
I say it with a great deal of sadness.
Many, in the last couple of years, the prices of books have gone prohibitively high.
A hardcover novel these days sells for anywhere from $15 to $20, and a paperback novel sells anywhere from $3 to $5 or even a little more.
and the consumer
the book buyer is shying away from the marketplace now
because he seems to feel there are better ways to spend
$20 or $5 even
as a result
the book sales have been dropping
and the publishers have become more and more selective
as to what they buy
unfortunately
that all gets passed down to the author
and
more and more frequently
in the last couple of years
I have had to turn away
as all my colleagues
in the agency business have had to do
I've had to turn away
a number
of very good books
that were well written
but didn't really fit
into certain categories
that I know are actively buying,
and so what you end up with
is a well-written book
that really isn't saleable,
and it can often break your heart
to send a book like that back.
It doesn't hurt you as much
to send back a bad book
as it does to send back a good one,
but there's nothing guaranteeing
that a good book
is going to sell,
and that I would say
is possibly the major difference between publishing today
and publishing 10 years ago.
Okay, one more follow-up on that.
Does the system, as you described it,
lead to sort of hack writing,
or writing that's not very good?
No, quite the contrary.
I think the level of writing is getting better
because publishers don't need to publish hack writing anymore
when they can get so many good writers.
The market has shrunk.
For instance, the paperback field, whereas about two or three years ago, there were, I would say, 13 active viable paperbacks
ranging from the modest size ones to the giant.
Several have gone out of business, and three or four more have been absorbed into other companies,
and now one can count six or seven paperback publishers left.
and so the clamor to be published by those houses is increasing
and so the publishers can afford to be more selective than ever before.
So my feeling is that, although I don't like to use the word hack,
that certainly the inferior writer is either going to have to try harder
or he's going to drop out because there are just too many good writers waiting to take his place.
Okay, Mr. Curtis I have about I want to move I have about 10 minutes left if you can spare that
I wanted to talk about some personal things about your background and your own work if you have the time for that
Absolutely
Okay, I was going to say how does one become an agent, but I guess I better ask how you became one
Well when I think for a long time I always wanted to be a writer
and when I got out of college,
I discovered that there were no real jobs for writers,
so I decided to get into a related field, publishing.
I could not find a job at a publishing company,
so I finally ended up working for a leading literary agency, Scott Merida,
and there I stayed for some seven or eight years,
and that was my apprenticeship.
and after some seven years
I really did have an itch to write
and so I had been writing
even while I worked for Scott Merida
so I left that firm
and became a freelance writer
and of course having been an agent
I was much better connected
than most freelance writers
could ever hope to be
so the transition was not as hard
for me as it would be
if somebody left some other job.
I did a lot of magazine work,
but eventually realized that the magazine market
was in its twilight,
and began focusing on books.
I wrote a lot of paperback novels,
and then eventually got into such areas as collaboration,
books on conservation.
I found that I had a forte in the area of humor
so I did a number of satirical books
I wrote just about anything that people would pay money for
and it was a very very good grounding
and after about five years of that
a number of my old clients looked me up
and asked me if I would represent them
and since I was not making a fortune as a writer
in spite of the fact that to date
I've had about 45 books published, I decided that perhaps I would go back into agenting,
and I started my own firm, and for two or three years, I was both a writer and a literary agent.
Literally, I had two desks back to back with a swivel chair between them,
and in the morning I would do one thing and in the afternoon I would do another
and I would try not to let one contaminate the other.
And eventually, when I discovered that I could make more money on a few phone calls as an agent
than I could for four or five months writing books,
it was pretty clear to me where my career was heading.
But I have not given up my writing.
The column, of course, is very satisfying.
And from time to time, I might take a crack at a commercial novel or a nonfiction book.
I get up at five or six in the morning,
I'll write for an hour or so,
then I'll go to work,
and although an hour a day may not seem like a lot,
as most professional writers will tell you,
over a period of a couple of months,
one can write a book at an hour a day
as long as you stay with it
and turn out something every day.
So I do consider myself a literary agent
with a side order of writing.
In looking over the books that I know you've written in the past few years,
it seems to me that a lot of your nonfiction books have been dealing with issues of social concern,
like the nuclear lessons, the inequality in American communities, and so forth.
Is that because of personal taste or because of your collaborator?
Well, I take some pride in some of the work that I've done in the area of conservation.
In around 1970 or so, I was approached by a woman who had accumulated a great deal of quite terrifying information about the nuclear power industry.
And she asked me to collaborate with her. I knew very little about it, but I did work with her.
And out of that collaboration came a book that was published by Doubleday called Perils of the Peaceful Atom.
It was the first popular book on the dangers of nuclear power plants.
And although it was supplanted later on by books published by people, authorities, scientists, and PhDs,
whereas we were only laymen and women,
I like to think that that book did open the door to discussion of the nuclear power issues,
which finally culminated in the Three Mile Island accident years later.
And I was able to say that I had told you so.
Many of the things that happened were predicted in that book years earlier,
and of course nobody really wanted to listen.
I have written some other books of social value
I'm very proud of them
I'm also, if I may add
very proud of an agent
to have brought into the world
many books on social issues
and things like that
we recently handled a magnificent first novel
about the Vietnam War called The Thirteenth Valley,
which went on the bestseller list,
and opened the door to what I know will now be
a state of Vietnam fiction.
Up until that time, people had said
that nobody really wanted to read about Vietnam,
and so we've now enabled some fresh air
to blow into the marketplace with that novel.
and again, this is an accomplishment that I'm very proud of.
What about your fiction, your novels?
Could you give me an idea of what kind of things you write about,
and if they sell well?
Well, a couple of years ago, while I was still full,
well, more than that, about a decade ago,
So I conceived a paperback series featuring a hero that I always thought was rather unusual.
He was a detective in the area of sports.
And a series of books featuring this hero was, the series was called The Pro, and the books
were published by Warner.
We did four of those, and at the moment I'm trying to revive that series or something along those lines
because right now, although there's a great deal of male action-adventure fiction being published,
everybody's getting bored with the same old heroes, the mercenaries, the dirty dozens, and a series like that.
And so I'm trying to get revived, this hero that I think is a rather refreshing one.
But I'm not able to do too much in the fiction area simply because of time.
Okay, I just have a couple more here.
I remember reading one of your columns where you mentioned,
I guess it was an innovation on your part as an agent where you contracted with a publicity firm for your clients and so forth.
I wondered if things like that that you've done for your clients might be a little different or innovative or whatever.
Well, every agent, of course, is trying to seek a better way to handle his clients and more advantages for his clients.
and one of the things that upsets me deeply is the fact that publishers are very reluctant to spend promotional money on any authors except the big-name celebrity authors.
and so I attempted
a couple of years ago
to rectify that
by asking my clients
in effect to chip in
each one of them would be in effect taxed
a couple of extra percentage points
of commission
and that tax would go towards a fund
which we used to hire a publicity agent
who would publicize The Little Guy.
And some of the campaigns were quite successful.
Some aspects of the campaign were not so successful.
And it was because of the inconsistency of the results
that we finally dropped the program.
But some of it has had lasting results
and it certainly created a lot of talk in the industry and among authors.
And it was, I thought, a noble experiment
in the area of getting the lesser-known authors publicized.
But it's still difficult.
The market inclines towards the big name,
and the struggle to become a big name is extremely intense,
and very, very few people emerge.
Okay, what about movie deals for books that are worthy of it?
Do you actively seek them out, or do movie houses come to you?
Well, it's a combination.
Most books that are published that are of any value at all
are covered by the movie studios, producers,
and the people in New York whose job it is to scout on behalf of various Hollywood interests.
So the chances are that if an agent is handling a good book at all,
it will have been seen in one way or another by producers, directors, studio people and so forth.
but they have amazing ways of getting hold of manuscripts,
no matter how secretive you try to be.
And so long before you're ready to show them,
they've already been exposed.
Nevertheless, if we get a hot manuscript
and we really think it's going to make a terrific book,
we actively try to find a movie producer for it.
And so sometimes the deals come to us
and sometimes we generate them.
Okay, that's about
I mean, there's lots of questions
I could keep on talking for a long time
but I think we have enough
and we've taken enough of your time
But listen, is there anything
anything I haven't asked
that you think listeners should know
or anything at all
that you'd like to talk about
while we still have some tape left?
No, I'd be happy to answer
any other questions you may have
Um, I will say that, uh, uh, we were talking about innovations before.
Um, I may be springing a very radical, uh, proposition on the publishing industry that
I believe will create a lot of talk and controversy, and I'm not doing it just to publicize myself,
but I've begun to, uh, because of my deep concern about royalty accounting, uh, and
and how publishers have managed to manipulate
and hide
authors' royalties,
I'm going to be making a proposal
to the publishing industry
about a radically different way
of accounting royalties
based not on sales,
but on copies printed.
And I would say that
within the next few months,
you might begin looking for
some stirring in that area
and I believe it could have some rather radical effects
on the way people think about the traditional way of accounting royalties.
Yeah, I remember some of your columns,
I think you sort of hinted at certain things about the way the publishers did that.
Right.
Well, I actually do suggest something like it in my book,
but I will now be amplifying on it

And if I can get some of the publishing media to pick up on these suggestions, it should make for very, very lively dialogue, and certainly one that's well overdue in this 18th century business we call publishing.
Well, I'd take it, then, in the, let's say, the three-part relationship here, a writer, an agent, and a publisher, that you would say probably the publisher has much the best of it?
No, I don't think so at all.
So I've heard everybody accuse everybody else of having the best of it.
There are rich agents, there are agents who are struggling,
there are rich authors and authors who are struggling,
and there are rich publishers and there are publishers who are struggling.
I, in spite of some of the belligerent things I may have said,
I have a great, great many friends among the publishers
and I want to see them do well.
And so I've come to think of it as a symbiotic environment
in which everybody really does depend on everybody else.
And an agent's job is not just to negotiate contracts,
but to negotiate interests so that nobody gets so badly hurt that he can't carry on.
I mean, publishers are always complaining about their overhead,
and it's well to remind them that agents have to pay their rent also.
But some agents get very greedy,
and they feel that the only way for an author to become famous
is to pin the publisher to the wall with a cruel deal.
and sometimes that can backfire in terms of how much money is left
after you've hit a publisher that hard,
how much money is left for the struggling author.
The paperback publisher that consistently pays $2 or $3 million
for one or two authors is going to find himself neglecting the new author
because he can't afford to pay him,
or if he should buy a new author's work,
he won't have any money left to publicize or promote that author's book.
So there's something even to be said for not being greedy
on behalf of your authors
and giving the publisher an even break.
Okay, very good.
Okay, listen, we're going to turn off the recorder.
